Comment: It's also important to note that the data reported on drug seizures at US borders only reflects the quantities that US Customs and Border Protection has *discovered.*   According to estimates by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the reported figures under-represent the drugs trafficked into the country. In 2021, the [DHS estimated](https://ohss.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/2023-12/2023_0703_plcy_fiscal_year_2022_border_security_metrics_report_2021_data_0.pdf) that they intercepted around 3% of the cocaine — the only drug measured in the study — trafficked through official ports of entry.   In contrast, DHS estimates that around 80% of people attempting to cross the border between ports of entry are intercepted, suggesting that the actual amount of fentanyl trafficked through unauthorized channels is also *under counted*, but to a lesser extent than through official ports.
Author: USAFacts
